{{Quote|The dead ruffians were laden on waggons and hauled off to an old sand-pit nearby and there buried: in the Battle Pit, as it was afterwards called.|Aftermath of the [[Battle of Bywater]]<ref name="scouring">{{RK|VI8}}, p. 1016</ref>}}

The '''Battle Pit''' was "an old sand-pit" near the town of [[Bywater]] in [[the Shire]] that was used as the burial place for the [[Ruffians]] killed during the [[Battle of Bywater]].<ref name="scouring" />

In ''[[The Atlas of Middle-earth]]'', [[Karen Wynn Fonstad]] speculated that the Battle Pit was located a short distance east of the town.<ref>{{HM|AME}}, "The Lord of the Rings", "The Battle of Bywater", p. 155</ref>

== History ==
On  [[3 November]] {{TA|3019}}, 100 [[Ruffians]] fought against 300 [[Hobbits]] on the [[Bywater Road]]. The Ruffians had foolishly walked into a trap within a banked portion of the road, which the Hobbits secured with barricades at either end. In the ensuing fight nearly seventy of the [[Men]] died. The victorious Hobbits loaded the bodies of their foes into wagons and hauled them to an old, nearby sand-pit for burial, which thereafter was called the Battle Pit. Nineteen Hobbits also died in the fray but they were buried separately, with honor in a hill-side grave above the Battle Pit. Sometime later, "a great stone was" placed over the hill-side grave and a garden grew around it.<ref name="scouring" />

== Other versions of the legendarium ==
In an early draft of the chapter "[[The Scouring of the Shire]]", the burial place of the Ruffians was originally "an old gravel-pit" that the Hobbits later named the '''Battle Pits'''. In this draft, there were no Hobbit casualties.<ref>{{SD|IX}}, p. 101</ref>

== Inspiration ==
In relation to the "great stone"<ref name="scouring" /> it was noted by Patricia Reynolds that while "the setting of memorial stones . . . is a widespread tradition", the garden that grew around the stone recalls a [[World War I]] tradition where "many English villages" would plant a "garden of remembrance" around their war-memorials.<ref>''[[Mythlore 19]]'', no 2, whole no. 72: "Funeral Customs in Tolkien's Fiction", p. 50</ref><ref>{{HM|RC}}, p. 662</ref>
